questions.question: An astronaut weighs 600 N on Earth. What would be the astronaut's weight on a planet that has the same mass as Earth but twice the radius?
questions.explanation: Since $F_g \propto 1/r^2$, doubling the distance ($2r$) results in a force of $1/2^2 = 1/4$ the original weight. $600 / 4 = 150$ N.

questions.question: Two masses, M and 4M, are separated by a distance L. At what distance from the smaller mass M is the net gravitational field zero?
questions.explanation: Set fields equal: $GM/x^2 = G(4M)/(L-x)^2$. Taking the square root: $1/x = 2/(L-x) \rightarrow L-x = 2x \rightarrow L = 3x \rightarrow x = L/3$.

questions.question: Planet Z has 4 times the mass of Earth and 2 times the radius of Earth. If Earth's surface gravity is g, what is the surface gravity on Planet Z?
questions.explanation: $g_{new} = G(4M)/(2R)^2 = 4GM/4R^2 = g$. The increase in mass is perfectly offset by the increase in radius squared.

questions.question: If the distance between two objects is reduced to one-third of its original value, what happens to the gravitational force between them?
options: It increases by a factor of 9.
It increases by a factor of 3.
It decreases by a factor of 9.
questions.explanation: By the inverse-square law, $F \propto 1/(1/3)^2 = 1/(1/9) = 9$ times the original force.

questions.question: Two planets, A and B, have the same average density, but Planet A has twice the radius of Planet B. What is the ratio of their surface gravities (gA / gB)?
questions.explanation: Mass $M \propto R^3$. Since $g = GM/R^2$, then $g \propto R^3/R^2$, so $g \propto R$. If radius doubles, $g$ doubles.

questions.question: Which of the following would cause the greatest increase in the gravitational force between two objects?
options: Doubling the mass of both objects.
Doubling the mass of one object.
questions.explanation: Halving distance increases force by 4x. Doubling both masses also increases force by 4x. In standardized testing, distance changes are emphasized due to the squared relationship.

questions.question: A point mass m is at the center of a thin uniform ring of mass M and radius R. What is the net gravitational force on the point mass m?
questions.explanation: Symmetry dictates that the gravitational pull from one side of the ring is perfectly cancelled by the pull from the opposite side.

questions.question: An object is released from a height h above the surface of a planet with radius R. If h = R, what is its acceleration upon release?
questions.explanation: Distance from center is $R + h = 2R$. Field strength $g_{local} = GM/(2R)^2 = g/4$.

questions.question: What is the gravitational field strength at a location where a 2.0 kg mass experiences a 10 N force?
questions.explanation: Field strength $g$ is force per unit mass: $g = F/m = 10\text{ N} / 2.0\text{ kg} = 5.0\text{ N/kg}$.

questions.question: A uniform lead sphere has surface gravity g. If it is reshaped into a single sphere with half the original volume, what is the new surface gravity?
questions.explanation: Volume halved means Mass is $M/2$. Radius becomes $R/2^{1/3}$. $g_{new} = G(M/2) / (R/2^{1/3})^2 = (1/2) / (1/2^{2/3}) g = 2^{-1/3} g \approx 0.79g$.

scoreMessages.90: Exceptional! You've mastered the complex proportionalities of universal gravitation.
scoreMessages.70: Good job! You have a solid handle on the inverse-square law and scaling factors.
scoreMessages.50: Decent effort. Review how radius changes affect the denominator in the gravity formula.
scoreMessages.0: Keep practicing! Focus on the $1/r^2$ relationship and measuring distance from the center.
